elephant: Elephants are the largest land animals on Earth and can weigh up to 14,000 pounds.
blue whale: The blue whale is the largest animal ever known to have existed, with individuals reaching lengths of up to 100 feet.
cheetah: Cheetahs are the fastest land animals, capable of reaching speeds up to 60-70 miles per hour.
honeybee: Honeybees communicate with each other by performing a dance known as the 'waggle dance'.
kangaroo: Kangaroos can leap distances of up to 30 feet in a single bound.
peregrine falcon: The peregrine falcon is the fastest bird, capable of diving at speeds over 200 miles per hour.
giraffe: Giraffes have the same number of neck vertebrae as humans, despite their long necks.
octopus: Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
platypus: The platypus is one of the few mammals that lay eggs instead of giving birth to live young.
dolphin: Dolphins have been observed using tools, such as sponges to protect their snouts while foraging.
bald eagle: Bald eagles have a wingspan of up to 8 feet.
ant: Some ant species can build living bridges with their bodies to cross gaps.
penguin: Emperor penguins can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet and stay underwater for more than 20 minutes.
ostrich: Ostriches are the largest birds and can run at speeds up to 45 miles per hour.
hummingbird: Hummingbirds are the only birds that can fly backward.
sea turtle: Some species of sea turtles can live for more than 100 years.
red fox: Red foxes use the Earth's magnetic field to hunt, aligning their attacks to increase success.
axolotl: Axolotls have the remarkable ability to regenerate lost limbs and other body parts.
albatross: Albatrosses have the largest wingspan of any bird, reaching up to 11 feet.
gorilla: Gorillas share approximately 98% of their DNA with humans.
